channel.title: Advanced In-depth Guide on Eclipse IDE
channel.description:
I have not seen this tutorial anywhere else in the whole off Moparscape. I have taken so much from you lovely Moparians, so I thought I'd contribute something that beginners, novice, etc (coders) would need. [b]Much research was put into this task[/b], so positive feedback is appreciated.
[hr]
[b]Table of Contents:[/b]
[ol][li]Small Summary on the IDE.[/li] [li]Downloading the Eclipse IDE.[/li] [li]Getting to Know the Basics.[/li] [li]How to Run Your Server on the IDE.[/li][/ol]
[hr]
[size=12pt][b]1.[/b] Small Summary on the IDE.[/size]
This programming tool has a multi-language software development environment; these programming languages include: Ada, C, C++, COBOL, Fortran, Haskell, JavaScript, Perl, PHP, Python, R, Ruby, Scala, Clojure, Groovy, Scheme, and Erlang. But the main language most Runescape private server developers use is Java. The Eclipse Platform uses plug-ins to provide all functionality within and on top of the runtime system, in contrast to some other applications. The Eclipse Platform's runtime system is based on Equinox, an implementation of the OSGi core framework specification.
[hr]
[size=12pt][b]2.[/b] Downloading the Eclipse IDE.[/size]
The Eclipse IDE can be found [url=http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/packages/eclipse-ide-java-ee-developers/junosr2]here[/url].
When you have arrived to the page, turn your head too the right. You should spot something, that looks like so:
[img]http://img17.imageshack.us/img17/4466/050b7bbc58594a23a25c13d.png[/img]
[b]64 Bit Computers (x64)[/b]
To have Eclipse working at it's highest most efficient rate, download the 64 bit version. You are able to download the 32 bit, but it's performance won't be as effective/efficient as the 64 bit.
Once you have downloaded the file for your selected file system, you should have a zip folder that looks like so:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/knirZ2R.png[/img]
Extract it to your desktop, which then should look like this:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/EmaVH6H.png[/img]
Simply open up the 'Eclipse' folder and open up the file "eclipse"; which would look like so:
[img]http://img832.imageshack.us/img832/3073/49b1377559ec4db1a43e913.png[/img]
These 2 windows will come up, just simply click "OK" or according to your liking where it says workspace rename it to whatever you'd like to it be.
[img]http://i.imgur.com/nvZd6Lv.png[/img]
You will then have successfully downloaded/installed Eclipse - the complete product is shown below.
[img]http://i38.tinypic.com/14uuvld.png[/img]
[hr]
[size=12pt][b]3.[/b] Getting to Know the Basics.[/size]
[size=10pt][b]3.1.[/b] Setting Up a Project.[/size]
While you have your Eclipse launched at the page you just had it at, in the top left corner there should be an icon that looks like so:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/XLI20bR.png[/img]
This will be where you can add your project for a numerous amount off programming languages. Hit the pull down menu, which looks like:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/WECropU.png[/img]
You'll need to press other. This should then pop-up:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/zIdin4c.png[/img]
Click 'Java Project' then Next.
This project setup page should appear.
[img]http://i.imgur.com/QVvPXjW.png[/img]
Fill it in accordingly; un-check the 'Use default location' then hit browse and head over to the root off your Source/Client directory.
[img]http://i.imgur.com/OfnSGh3.png[/img]
You then may press "Finish" which will then process your Source/Client and add it to your Package Explorer. Finished product:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/gjKdp6L.png[/img]
[b]Will be adding on everyday.[/b]
[hr]
[size=12pt][b]4.[/b] How to Run Your Server on the IDE.[/size]
On your main page, highlight you're source's package, like so:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/g0zqkcm.png[/img]
Then click "Run Configurations"
[img]http://i38.tinypic.com/2unvp6x.png[/img]
This should then pop-up:
[img]http://i33.tinypic.com/24pxiy9.png[/img]
I will be doing this as PI based.
In this input:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/8QrwpbR.png[/img]
Write: [code]server.Server[/code]
Then hit "Apply" then "Run".
Down the bottom your finished product:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/4RIE9To.png[/img]
[hr]
[b]A lot more will be added/tidied up soon, please leave [i]positive[/i] feedback.[/b]

I guess you should mention the useful hotkeys which Eclipse has like
CTRL + SHIFT + O - This will automatically organizes imports.
CTRL + SHIFT + F - Formats code (Eg. tabs parameters in methods).

item.title: Advanced In-depth Guide on Eclipse IDE
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

Jayden.:

Much research was put into this task

Doesn’t look like it.

Jayden.:

The Eclipse IDE can be found here.

HcoJustin:

Why the enterprise edition? It includes a few more version control options out of the box, but doesn’t include their smarter code analysis. I highly doubt you’d be making use of Java EE, and if you were you wouldn’t be coming here to learn how to use the IDE. (Download is almost half the size too!)

Jayden.:

To have Eclipse working at it’s highest most efficient rate, download the 64 bit version. You are able to download the 32 bit, but it’s performance won’t be as effective/efficient as the 64 bit.

Doesn’t point out that you need to have a Java build with the matching architecture.

Jayden.:

Once you have downloaded the file for your selected file system

Not a file system, it is an architecture.

Jayden.:

This will be where you can add your project for a numerous amount off programming languages. Hit the pull down menu, which looks like:

Not all of those are programming languages.

Jayden.:

You’ll need to press other. This should then pop-up:

If you didn’t use the enterprise edition Java project would be a default on that menu.

You also don’t cover adding external libraries. If a server didn’t have an existing eclipse .classpath file then it will not know where to find them.

Read full topic
item.source: Advanced In-depth Guide on Eclipse IDE
